title: How to Reset a DSC Alarm

steps.headline: Open the access door and enter your master code twice.
steps.description: Pull down the panel that covers the keypad on your alarm system. After this, simply enter your 4 digit master code, wait 2 seconds, and then enter it again. On some models, this step will reset the alarm and stop it from ringing. This step will also reset the trouble light, armed light, and memory light. If your alarm is still ringing, complete the rest of the steps below.

steps.headline: Hold down the reset button for 2 seconds.
steps.description: This button is usually located on the bottom right side of the keypad. Hold it down for at least 2 seconds to disengage the alarm. You will notice the lights on the alarm change from red to green to signal that the alarm has been reset. This also helps to reset the low battery light once the power has been restored.

steps.headline: Press “*72” if the alarm is still ringing.
steps.description: Use the keypad to enter the code “*72.” This resets the smoke sensors, which will cause the alarm to stop if it is still ringing. If your keypad has an “Enter” button, press this once you have entered the code. If you accidentally press the wrong number on the keypad, simply press the exit button and then re-enter the code.

methods.name: Figuring out Why the Alarm Sounded

steps.headline: Check for power failure.
steps.description: This is the most common reason for DSC alarms to unexpectedly ring. Check if the lights on the property are working to ascertain if the power is currently on. If the power is out and the alarm is ringing, this indicates that the batteries in the alarm system are dead and need to be replaced. Contact your power company for information about recent power outages in your area.

steps.headline: Search the area for signs of an intruder.
steps.description: Your DSC alarm system is designed to alert you of unusual motion in and around your property. Check your property for any signs of intrusion, such as broken windows, stolen goods, and dirty footprints inside. If you have a video monitoring system on your property, check the footage to rule out the possibility of an intruder.

steps.headline: Check for smoke and fire around the property.
steps.description: If you can’t find any signs of fire on your property, consider if there has been any smoke that could have triggered the smoke detectors. Burnt toast, birthday candles, and a smoking pot on the stove can sometimes trigger sensitive smoke detectors. If you had to press ”*72” to reset your alarm, this indicates that smoke was most likely the reason for your alarm ringing.

steps.headline: Investigate if the phone lines are working.
steps.description: If your alarm is connected to the phone lines, temporary phone outages can cause the alarm to ring. Call your phone provider from your mobile phone to find out if there have been any phone line problems in your area.

text: Fixing the Alarm Open the access door and enter your master code twice. Pull down the panel that covers the keypad on your alarm system. After this, simply enter your 4 digit master code, wait 2 seconds, and then enter it again. On some models, this step will reset the alarm and stop it from ringing. This step will also reset the trouble light, armed light, and memory light. If your alarm is still ringing, complete the rest of the steps below. Hold down the reset button for 2 seconds. This button is usually located on the bottom right side of the keypad. Hold it down for at least 2 seconds to disengage the alarm. You will notice the lights on the alarm change from red to green to signal that the alarm has been reset. This also helps to reset the low battery light once the power has been restored. Press “*72” if the alarm is still ringing. Use the keypad to enter the code “*72.” This resets the smoke sensors, which will cause the alarm to stop if it is still ringing. If your keypad has an “Enter” button, press this once you have entered the code. If you accidentally press the wrong number on the keypad, simply press the exit button and then re-enter the code. Figuring out Why the Alarm Sounded Check for power failure. This is the most common reason for DSC alarms to unexpectedly ring. Check if the lights on the property are working to ascertain if the power is currently on. If the power is out and the alarm is ringing, this indicates that the batteries in the alarm system are dead and need to be replaced. Contact your power company for information about recent power outages in your area. Search the area for signs of an intruder. Your DSC alarm system is designed to alert you of unusual motion in and around your property. Check your property for any signs of intrusion, such as broken windows, stolen goods, and dirty footprints inside. If you have a video monitoring system on your property, check the footage to rule out the possibility of an intruder. Check for smoke and fire around the property. If you can’t find any signs of fire on your property, consider if there has been any smoke that could have triggered the smoke detectors. Burnt toast, birthday candles, and a smoking pot on the stove can sometimes trigger sensitive smoke detectors. If you had to press ”*72” to reset your alarm, this indicates that smoke was most likely the reason for your alarm ringing. Investigate if the phone lines are working. If your alarm is connected to the phone lines, temporary phone outages can cause the alarm to ring. Call your phone provider from your mobile phone to find out if there have been any phone line problems in your area.
